Award.AwardTitle: Janus Brushblock Copolymer Phase Behavior: Morphology and Thermodynamics
Award.AbstractNarration:
Part I: NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY

Specialty polymers that form precise and tailorable structures at the nanometer length scale (1/10000th of the width of a human hair) provide a route for developing useful porous membranes for selective water and gas purifications, as well as templates for patterning faster computer microprocessors with ever smaller components. This research program will educate the next generation of scientists and engineers in the guided design and development of such polymers, within an interdisciplinary research group situated at the interface between chemistry, chemical engineering, and materials science. Through combination of advanced polymer synthesis, detailed structural characterization at the nanoscale, and characterization of the resulting polymer properties, this project will reveal new molecular design rules for nonlinear polymers that lead to their spontaneous self-organization at length scales below 15 nanometers. These studies will provide American industry with technological knowledge that enables the development of innovative products that maintain global competitiveness. The educational outreach activities associated with this project will focus on the development of simple, visually attractive demonstrations featuring spontaneous self-organization of macroscopic materials into structures visible to the naked eye. These demonstrations will furnish opportunities for educating and exciting students at the K-12 and college levels, as well as the general public, about advanced technologies based on polymers.



Part 2: TECHNICAL SUMMARY

Block polymers self-assemble into a variety of nanostructured morphologies, as a consequence of the molecular frustration induced by coupling two or more immiscible polymer segments into a single macromolecule. A delicate thermodynamic balance governs the lowest degree of polymerization (N) at which an AB diblock polymer microphase separates, which then dictates the smallest microdomain size that can form. One potential block polymer application relies on their periodic microdomains as templates for advanced microelectronics and mesoporous inorganic materials with sub-15 nm features. A common approach to reducing diblock polymer domain sizes is to decrease N, while increasing the chemical incompatibility of the A and B segments. However, applications of these new materials often require costly development of new materials processing protocols. This project investigates the microphase separation behavior of Janus bottlebrush polymers, a nonlinear polymer architecture derived from covalently linking linear AB diblocks through their junctions, as a new means for driving AB diblocks to self-assemble at smaller length scales than their linear homologs. Using a combination of small-angle X-ray scattering, transmission electron microscopy, and rheological measurements, the phase behaviors of Janus bottlebrushes will be studied as a function of their compositions, the chemical incompatibility between the homopolymer arms, and the graft density of the bristles along the backbone.

Institution.Name: University of Minnesota-Twin Cities
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MINNESOTA

POR.DRECONTENT:
Over 300 million metric tons of plastics are produced worldwide each year by virtue of their myriad applications, which stem from many monomer molecules being linked into giant chains known as polymers. One means of expanding the remarkable array of useful polymer properties is to link two or more polymer chains of different monomer units into a molecular composite called a block copolymer. The properties of block copolymers are often greater than the simple sum of the properties of their constituents, because block copolymers form periodic structures at nanoscopic length scales comparable to 1/100,000th of the thickness of a sheet of paper. Block copolymers with otherwise inaccessible combinations of useful properties find potential applications in renewable energy storage and use, as water purification membranes, and as templates for advanced microchip manufacturing.

 

Intellectual Merit:

     While relationships between the physical properties and chemical structures of linear block copolymers are well-understood, this project focused on understanding such relationships in polymers with nonlinear structures. Research supported by this NSF award specifically elucidated how densely grafting block copolymer pendants from a polymer backbone as in a brush block polymer yields new relationships between chemical structure and physical properties. By combining precision polymer synthesis methods with materials characterization techniques such as synchrotron X-ray scattering and rheological measurements, this project revealed new insights into how nonlinear brush block polymers enable periodic structure formation with sub-10 nanometer features. These fundamental scientific studies suggest that nonlinear copolymers offer unique attributes for potential applications in microelectronic device manufacturing and as membranes for size-selective molecular separations. Research results from this project have been disseminated in peer-reviewed journal publications and scientific conference presentations.

 

Broader Impact:

     This award has significantly supported the training of six graduate students and one undergraduate, including three women, in cross-disciplinary materials science, chemical engineering, and chemistry research. One Ph.D. and two Master?s Degrees have been granted based on this award. Given the industrial importance of polymers, project participants engaged industrial partners through oral research presentations and short course lectures on advanced polymer synthesis and characterization techniques. Project participants also engaged the general public through interactive demonstrations and discussions about the merits and demerits of plastics use through events hosted by the annual University of Minnesota (UMN) Materials Week science carnival, outreach activities at the Minnesota State Fair, a flash talk at the UMN Bell Museum of Natural History, and a science outreach program targeting under-served middle school students in the Twin Cities.

 


Last Modified: 05/31/2021
Modified by: Mahesh K Mahanthappa
